On the feedback so far, I would love to know what aspects of the programme have been appreciated. The witnesses touched on what help these kids usually need, but I would love to hear about the feedback. What criteria will determine the terms of the pilot being made permanent and expanded?
I am learning a lot today. I want to know about the requisite qualifications for the role. Am I correct in saying that there is an educational role and therapeutic role?
I take it the Deputy is referring to the primary pilot. Is that correct?
Yes.

An external evaluation of strands 1 and 2 of the pilot is being carried out by the Centre for Effective Services. The idea is that the pilot will run to June 2026 while the evaluation is being considered. Although we cannot pre-empt the final outcome of the evaluation, it will inform the next steps. We would, of course, love to see this rolled out to other schools.

As I said, the evaluation is continuing and we do not have the final results or outcome. However, we know that there is positive feedback from schools and parents and many have called for the continuation of the pilot. Schools are seen as a safe and appropriate place for counselling.

The Deputy asked about qualifications. There is no national regulatory body for counsellors in Ireland. Bearing that in mind, we went to the main accrediting bodies for counsellors and liaised with the HSE, which has run a national counselling service for over 20 years. Its representative is on the selection committee for counsellors. They have to be suitably qualified and have experience of working with children. They also have to be an accredited member with one of six organisations. That gives us oversight and governance of counsellors.

On strand 2, the education and well-being practitioners' role is based on a UK model which has mental health support teams in schools. We are recruiting psychology, education and social science graduates. We have some people who were psychologists and also teachers in strand 2. They come with a wealth of experience, as well as a qualification. We give them extensive training. Our psychologists have developed an induction programme, but we also get external experts in to give them some interventions.
We have retention and recruitment problems across many sectors in the State. Does that affect NEPS?

We have run three or four competitions for the education and well-being practitioner, EWP, role. Psychology graduates often go on to further education. Many have bursaries to come back to NEPS. They will hit the ground running when they come back to us because they have had such experience. It is seen as a stepping stone. The UK experiences the same. However, the UK has a particular qualification. It has partnered with universities to train EWPs. Graduates get accredited qualifications and there is a career pathway in the UK. We have examined that model. If this was to go forward, it would be very interesting for people to have a career path as an EWP rather than it being seen as a stepping stone to another career.

That is great. I was a teacher for over 20 years and many of my friends are still teachers. A major worry for me is the recruitment and retention problem in the sector. Our teachers are overburdened and we are losing a lot of them. Young teachers who have qualified face an excessive workload. A lot of teachers are retiring early. Will this put extra pressure on teachers? Teachers are always getting extra jobs put on them. Will this be another issue for our teachers? What is in place for the well-being of our teachers so that we can keep them?

If anything, strands 1 and 2 of the NEART programme take the pressure off teachers in that they build on capacity in the system and there is extra provision with an add-on to be able to support them in their work in terms of training and their understanding of mental health. That is provided through the in-school support of counsellors and EWPs for capacity building and universal supports through the NEART programme. In-training person should support teams. Ms Mulhern mentioned that we are focusing on teacher well-being as part of the NEART work because we understand and know the demands on them. We are acutely aware of the pressure and need in the school system.
NEPS is not worried that this will add additional pressure to our-----
We hope we are trying to support them by doing the work we are doing as opposed to adding pressure.

That concludes our main body of questioning. We will now go back to members, who can each have two minutes, and then to witnesses. Another Deputy has joined us. Deputy Conor D. McGuinness is very welcome. He is not ordinarily a member of the committee, but he is interested in participating. We will get a question from him.

I did not have time to delve into this in huge detail during the first round of questions. I refer to the review of the first pilot in 2023 and 2024. The witnesses said it was sent out to tender. How much did that tender cost? What was the name of the company?
The name of the company is the Centre for Effective Services.
The exact cost of the tender was €80,000.

I have an issue in that this is time-sensitive data. This changes with the years but a nine-month pilot project has taken almost two years to review, collect data and report back on the effectiveness of the pilot. Are the officials satisfied with the current timeframe of the review? It was May 2024 when the schools broke for the summer and we are heading into 2026 and we still do not have the report gathered and the feedback collated because we do not have the data back from the review company.
The pilot began in 2023, so it is still running. It is running until June 2026. It was initially a one-year pilot but it was extended.
I know, but Ms Eustace said the data from the first year of the pilot will be available in the next few weeks, more than 18 months on from when that pilot school year of 2023-24 ended.
CES gathered the data this summer, so it will be looking at the last two years.

Is it good practice to leave it until the summer just gone, 12 months after the pilot ended for the first year, to start gathering data when it is, as I said, time-sensitive? I am going to run over time, but it is important to have this in a current format.

I understand that. In the initial stages of the pilot we found it difficult to recruit counsellors. We were also engaged with recruiting education well-being practitioners, which took time. The pilot rolled on to another year so we could see the effect of it.

I get that, but there were 782 students in the first year, according to the data here. Out of that, why did it take 18 months to be anywhere near having the data back? Will the witnesses give me a yes-no answer on whether they think it is good practice for them to leave it that long to get the data back from a project that took place?
I thank the Senator. It is a yes-no answer.
I suppose we were waiting to see the implementation of it over a two-year period.
Okay. Our next member is Deputy Roche.
I thank the Chair. My question is based on the evidence and outcomes from Neart. Beyond registration numbers, what concrete indicators demonstrate improved student well-being or attendance?

I will take that. As was said, it is a very new programme. It only really started delivering content in March of this year so it is early days. We have a really thorough evaluation plan that covers every single aspect of it. For example, as soon as a webinar, masterclass or any event is completed, we get live feedback and review that within a day of it ending. That allows us to take ongoing quality improvement measures. We also have live feedback from students, where in the teacher-led, classroom-based courses the last slide of the course has a QR code and a link so that students can give us feedback. That comes directly to us. We are not depending on the schools to have to gather and deliver that. We have also developed a partnership with the school of psychology in the University of Limerick. We are working with it to do a much more thorough evaluation, specifically for student support team members who have that additional level of responsibility for student mental health and well-being, so we have a three-phase project with them. We have only started gathering data, so I cannot report back on it, but it is very thorough. It is looking at what they feel is the appropriateness and feasibility of implementing the content and looking at what implementation is happening on the ground. We have focused on that to date but we are starting to develop a parent evaluation plan as well, so again we are getting live feedback from parents all the time. We are very conscious the current Neart cycle ends in summer 2027 and we are very focused on that.

We never got to go through the second part of my submission at the start, which related to whether there is going to be a unified response to children being harassed or bullied online by people they are in school with. I have seen a school advise the parents that if it is happening online, even though it is students in the class, it is nothing to do with the school. We saw earlier in the year with a boxing club that when somebody took matters outside the club, they were expelled from it, which was the right thing to do. If children are being bullied online by people from their class, do we have an approach to that?

It is very likely that will come into the classroom and into the school. As the Senator is probably aware, there is a lot of work being done with the Cineáltas action plan for schools. New procedures have issued to schools and there is training for schools on how to deal with bullying incidents. Bullying record-keeping has been updated and improved. There is a lot happening in that space and it is being monitored very closely. Schools can consult their allocated psychologist depending on what happens, if it seriously impacts the child in any particular way. Often it is an issue for the school's code of behaviour as to how it might manage that, depending on the case, the issue and the emerging needs.
But right now should the school be handling that?
Yes, there are various policies in schools. They have to have a bullying policy, which is monitored-----
Even though it is happening online outside school, but with students from the school.
It is very likely that comes into the classroom-----
Absolutely. It does.

-----because it is about the relationship between young people. It does not just stay online. There will be the non-verbals and things happening, so it can very much impact on the learning and the relationships within the school setting. It would be very unusual for that to be only in the online space.

Ba mhaith liom ceist a chur ar na finnéithe maidir le seirbhísí atá acu trí mheán na Gaeilge do Ghaelscoileanna agus don Ghaeltacht. I would like to ask the witnesses about what services are available for Gaelscoileanna and an Ghaeltacht. An bhfuil breis deacrachtaí? Are there additional challenges to offering these supports, because of the language, for students and teachers?

In strand 1 and strand 2, we have Gaelscoileanna and we have two counsellors on the panel who are able to deliver the service through Irish. A number of the EWPs are Gaeilgeoirí, so we have developed a number of inputs for specifically for our Gaelscoileanna. We in the NEPS also translate all our documentation. Part of strand 2 is a lot of resources for schools and parents to support their children. They are one-pagers. We have those translated into Irish as well.

Do these all become available at the same time? Usually we have to wait longer. Has it had any effect? When the schools were being chosen, were we limited in how many Gaelscoileanna we could choose because of staffing?

No. For strand 1, all the schools in the seven counties are included in the pilot. For strand 2, we had clusters of schools in particular areas, including Dublin 16, Dublin 7, Cork and Carlow. We located them in particular areas but we included Gaelscoileanna. Those were the selection criteria.

The handiest thing is probably for me to throw out all my questions at once. Especially with the NEPS, I am delighted to hear the service is provided as Gaeilge and that schools in the Gaeltacht are not left waiting an additional amount of time, although I understand there is often waiting time involved. Is it possible to get some sense of where things are at with Irish Sign Language? Is there a service available for deaf people and people who use Irish Sign Language? Another question that comes up is related to co-ordination with local suicide prevention officers and the national office for suicide prevention. It is tragic, but sometimes we see a suicide or even a cluster of suicides in a community – not necessarily in the school community – which can have a deep impact on children as they attend school. That can create ripples in the schools community as part of the overall community.
Is there a level of co-ordination there in terms of responding and a co-ordinated response in a given geographic area or a given community?

Another issue that constantly arises - I am sure the witnesses hear it an awful lot - is the allocation of NEPS hours for individual schools where there may be extended waiting lists that are particularly pronounced and creating a particular difficulty for that school and for children attending it.

I have some questions for Jigsaw. I represent Waterford. No doubt the representatives know there is a long-running demand and campaign to have a physical Jigsaw service, notwithstanding the fact that some of the national services are available online and through other media, to people in Waterford as well. Will this support the roll-out, and do those physical Jigsaw presences support the roll-out in geographical areas of the Neart programme and that engagement Jigsaw has with NEPS in the school system in general? I just wish to get a sense of some of Jigsaw's partnership work with local organisations. There is a fantastic mental health organisation in Waterford called Laochas and it has a programme called inside out for secondary schools. Is there a level of co-ordination or communication in that regard?
Deputy, you have used up your time. The witnesses can have a wrap-up statement at the end where they can deal with some of those questions.
Perfect.
I call Deputy Jen Cummins.

I will go back to two things we did not get to cover the last time. One was the resources the witnesses will need for strands 1 and 2 to be expanded. Second, is there a possibility of rolling out north-east inner city-type supports, which are there already from the point of view of psychological and emotional support, to Ballymun and the south-west inner city?
Where to start? Ms McGrory will speak to Jigsaw in Waterford first.

I will. Deputy McGuinness will be aware that just in this year's budget additional resources have been provided to Jigsaw to provide a Jigsaw hub service in Waterford and south Kilkenny and south Wexford. We are absolutely delighted about that. That work is beginning now and we are looking at all the collaborations we can build in terms of getting that service up off the ground. There will be an outreach service to Clare from our Limerick Jigsaw service as well. I hope that answers the Deputy's question. Obviously, as we do with all our other service locations, we work with all partners in whatever way we can to ensure that all young people have access to the service when they need it.
Ms Eustace will speak to the suicide prevention officer, CI and the north-east inner city.

Deputy Cummins asked what resources we need for strand 1 and strand 2 to roll out. We would need additional counsellors and additional education well-being practitioners. The evaluation report is being finalised. We hope that will outline what is needed into the system and will advise us on future policy and expansion. As I said earlier, we would welcome any expansion of these really positive resources.

In relation to the north-east inner city, I was involved in that pilot. It continues to roll out where they have speech and language therapists, OTs and psychology supports. We know that NEPS psychologists are given extra time to work in our DEIS schools.

We will have time for the witnesses to summarise. I am conscious that the times keep moving. I have just two brief questions. I want to ask Jigsaw, is a lot of your Neart programme currently virtually based, and do you plan on moving it more into a face-to-face realm? Also, it was a recommendation of the former Oireachtas committee on education that a high-level steering group would be established as a priority. This was key recommendation No. 7 in our report. Has progress been made on that?

I will take your first question. Yes, at the moment, quite a lot of the offerings for schools are virtual. We are offering our programme of work to all post-primary schools across the country. There are 750 post-primary schools. Essentially, we have a very small team. We have only four people on the team in Jigsaw, so we are doing our very best to try to maximise the reach in the best ways we possibly can. When we do provide virtual webinars and so on, we provide them repeatedly so they are at different times of the day and in the evening in order that as many school staff as possible can engage with us. It is a matter of trying to be as flexible as possible. Of course, we would love to have further resources to be able to do a lot more in person. Our student support team regional conferences are a really good example of that, where there is really significant engagement in all eight of those and numbers registered and oversubscribed, as Ms Mulhern mentioned earlier. We would love to be able to do much more in person and engage with schools in that way much more, but, for the moment, the resources allow for us only to be mainly virtual.
May I just check the question about the high-level steering group? Was that referring to Jigsaw or the Department of education? I was not clear.
The Department of education.

We have a well-being steering group in the Department chaired by our assistant secretary, Martina Mannion. That brings all the sections of the Department together and we meet regularly because well-being is everybody's responsibility. Neart feeds into that steering group, the counselling pilot feeds into that steering group, and we have an interagency group as well that we feed into.

Sorry, but I have to follow the rules on times as well. We have concluded with members' questions. I know there are a lot of loose ends you may need to tidy up in four minutes, if you could maybe apportion it between yourselves and wrap up some of that.
Ms Eustace can speak to NOSP, I will deal with NEPS for Deputy McGuinness, and then we will conclude with Neart.

I will speak about NOSP. We liaise on an ongoing basis with the National Office for Suicide Prevention and the resource officers for suicide prevention. We met with them nationally in June, and now, in each of our regions, our regional psychologists are meeting with them at local level. I am also on the Connecting for Life steering committee and on the expert advisory group for the new national suicide prevention strategy, the revision of Connecting for Life. They are really important for linkage with us in relation to suicide clusters, etc., and we work very well with them.

In relation to the NEPS time in schools, it is through days. We allocate the time depending on the size and the needs of the school. Our issue is our staffing levels, which we are growing at the moment. As mentioned earlier, we have a lot of psychologists coming through in training, thankfully. Up to 60 could be coming on board over the next three years as well as the ongoing recruitment competition. The more staff we have the more time we can allocate to our schools. We want to be in schools more and we want to grow our staffing.

Finally, on Neart, I work really closely with Ms Mulhern and Ms McGrory here leading out on the programme. It is really a new collaboration and new for our Department working with Jigsaw in this way. It has been a really positive first nine months and we want to grow the work we are doing here. It has been a real pleasure to work with Jigsaw. We have learnt a lot from each other and it is a really good collaboration, with learning and sharing that we hope will continue further.
I will pass to Ms McGrory to have the last word.

I am stuck by the real interest in the parent components of Neart and with all the parents who have engaged, as members have said. We are trying to find as many ways as possible to get the information about Neart out to parents. Even already we have over 1,800 parents who are registered with us, and there is really significant participation in our webinars. We can track the number of listens to the podcast, etc. All that information is there, all the back catalogue is there and we send a monthly newsletter. If there is any way we can provide members with information in order that they can circulate that to their constituents, we would love to be able to do that in order that the information gets out to parents as well as the schools in their constituencies. Anything we can provide, we would love to do that.

We have one minute left. We really welcome the opportunity to answer the questions today. It has been quite an experience, one that none of us have had before, and it is great to showcase some of the innovative practice. We know we have a lot more to do. We really look forward to the well-being policy review to be able to get feedback from our stakeholders to continue to grow this work in the system that we know it is very much needed.

On behalf of our members, I sincerely thank you. You are pioneering something here that we are all very supportive of. No doubt we will have to have you back here again because hopefully more money will be put behind this and there will be more resourcing. In particular, I did not realise Jigsaw had only four people. It is a matter of trying to roll this out nationally. A lot more can be done. I think you will have a lot of support from within this room. I sincerely thank you all for your engagement this morning at the committee.
It has been very beneficial and informative.
As always, I thank the secretariat, our technical team and everyone else who has made the meeting possible.
Our committee now stands adjourned until Wednesday, 12 November 2025, at 12.30 p.m., in private session, to be followed immediately by a meeting in public session.

debateSection.summary: The joint committee adjourned at 11.30 a.m. until 12.30 p.m. on Wednesday, 12 November 2025.
